responses: Hello! How can I help you with air quality today?

Sad to see you go. Stay safe!

patterns: What is the air quality index
What does air quality index measure
responses: The Air Quality Index (AQI) is a number used by government agencies to communicate to the public how polluted the air currently is or how polluted it is forecast to become.
AQI stands for Air Quality Index. It tells you how clean or polluted the air is, and what associated health effects might be a concern for you.
The AQI is a standardized indicator of air quality. It runs from 0-500, where higher values indicate worse air quality and greater health concerns.
PM2.5 refers to atmospheric particulate matter (PM) that have a diameter of less than 2.5 micrometers. These fine particles can penetrate deep into the lungs and enter the bloodstream.
PM2.5 are tiny particles in the air that reduce visibility and cause the air to appear hazy when levels are elevated. They are a major concern for health.
PM2.5 are fine inhalable particles with diameters 2.5 micrometers and smaller. They're about 30 times smaller than a human hair!
PM10 are inhalable particles, with diameters that are generally 10 micrometers and smaller. Examples include dust, pollen, and mold.
PM10 refers to particulate matter 10 micrometers or less in diameter. They can irritate your eyes, nose, and throat.
PM10 are coarse particles that include dust, pollen, and mold spores. While larger than PM2.5, they can still cause respiratory issues.

patterns: Why should I care about AQI?
Can air pollution make me sick?
What are health risks of pollution
How does bad air affect me
responses: Air pollution can cause respiratory diseases, heart problems, stroke, and lung cancer. Short-term exposure can irritate the eyes, nose, and throat.
High AQI levels can lead to coughing, wheezing, and shortness of breath. Long-term exposure is linked to chronic conditions like asthma and heart disease.
Air pollution affects everyone, but especially children, elderly, and those with existing respiratory conditions. It can reduce lung function and increase hospital admissions.

patterns: What should I do if AQI is high?
How to protect myself from pollution?
How to stay safe in pollution
What to do when air is bad
responses: Wear a mask (N95/N99), use air purifiers indoors, avoid outdoor exercise, and keep windows closed.
Limit outdoor activities, stay hydrated, and use an air purifier if available. Sensitive groups should stay indoors.
During high AQI days: Stay indoors, use AC with HEPA filters, avoid cooking with gas, and reschedule outdoor activities.

patterns: How do I use this website?
responses: Air Aware lets you track real-time AQI, view historical trends, see a map of pollution levels, and get health recommendations.
You can search for any city to get its current Air Quality Index, view pollutant breakdowns (PM2.5, PM10, etc.), and see forecasted trends.
The dashboard provides real-time AQI monitoring, historical data visualization, pollution maps, and personalized health alerts.
Air Aware was built to help you stay informed about the air you breathe. We are a team dedicated to raising awareness about air quality.
This project is developed to provide accessible air quality data to everyone.
Our team is passionate about environmental health and created this tool to make air quality information accessible to all.
The major pollutants are PM2.5, PM10, Ozone (O3), Nitrogen Dioxide (NO2), Sulfur Dioxide (SO2), and Carbon Monoxide (CO).
AQI is calculated based on several pollutants, mainly Particulate Matter (PM2.5 and PM10), Ozone, NO2, SO2, and CO.
Key pollutants monitored include: Particulate Matter (PM2.5, PM10), Ground-level Ozone, Nitrogen Dioxide, Sulfur Dioxide, and Carbon Monoxide.
0-50: Good (Green), 51-100: Moderate (Yellow), 101-150: Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups (Orange), 151-200: Unhealthy (Red), 201-300: Very Unhealthy (Purple), 301+: Hazardous (Maroon).
Good is 0-50. Anything above 100 serves as a warning for sensitive groups, and above 300 is considered hazardous to everyone.
The AQI uses a color-coded system: Green (Good), Yellow (Moderate), Orange (Unhealthy for Sensitive), Red (Unhealthy), Purple (Very Unhealthy), Maroon (Hazardous).
Ground-level ozone (O3) is formed when pollutants from vehicles and industry react with sunlight. It can cause breathing problems and aggravate asthma.
Ozone is a major component of smog. While the ozone layer protects us, ground-level ozone is harmful and can damage lung tissue.
O3 forms during hot, sunny days when vehicle emissions react with heat and sunlight. It peaks in summer months and can trigger respiratory issues.
Nitrogen Dioxide (NO2) is a reddish-brown gas formed from vehicle emissions and power plants. It can irritate airways and worsen asthma.
NO2 comes primarily from vehicle exhaust and industrial processes. High levels can reduce lung function and increase respiratory infections.
Nitrogen dioxide is produced by burning fuel. It contributes to smog formation and can cause breathing difficulties, especially in children.
Sulfur Dioxide (SO2) is produced by burning fossil fuels at power plants and industrial facilities. It can cause breathing problems and aggravate heart disease.
SO2 contributes to acid rain and smog. Short-term exposure can harm the respiratory system, especially for those with asthma.
Sulfur dioxide comes mainly from coal-burning power plants. It can make breathing difficult and worsen existing respiratory conditions.
Carbon Monoxide (CO) is a colorless, odorless gas from vehicle exhaust and burning fuel. It reduces oxygen delivery to the body's organs.
CO is particularly dangerous because it's invisible and odorless. High levels can cause dizziness, confusion, and can be fatal.
Carbon monoxide is produced by incomplete combustion of fuels. It's most common near busy roads and can cause headaches and fatigue.
Children are especially vulnerable to air pollution because their lungs are still developing and they breathe more air per pound of body weight than adults.
Protect children by limiting outdoor play when AQI is above 100, keeping them hydrated, and using air purifiers at home.
Kids breathe faster and are more active outdoors, increasing their pollution exposure. High AQI can trigger asthma attacks and affect lung development.
Elderly people are at higher risk from air pollution due to weakened immune systems and pre-existing health conditions like heart disease.
Seniors should stay indoors when AQI is high, take medications as prescribed, and monitor symptoms closely.
Older adults are more susceptible to pollution's effects on the heart and lungs. They should avoid outdoor activities during poor air quality days.

patterns: Should I run when AQI is high
responses: Avoid outdoor exercise when AQI is above 150. If you must exercise, do it early morning or late evening when pollution is lower, and reduce intensity.
Exercise indoors when air quality is poor. If outdoors, avoid high-traffic areas and peak traffic hours.
During exercise you breathe deeper and faster, inhaling more pollutants. Switch to indoor workouts when AQI exceeds 100 if you're in a sensitive group.
N95 or N99 masks are effective against PM2.5. Surgical masks offer limited protection. Ensure proper fit for maximum effectiveness.
For pollution protection, use masks rated N95, N99, or FFP2/FFP3. They filter out at least 95% of particles including PM2.5.
Regular cloth masks don't protect against pollution. Use certified N95/N99 masks and ensure they seal properly around your face.
Air purifiers with HEPA filters can remove 99.97% of particles including PM2.5. Choose one sized appropriately for your room.
Look for air purifiers with True HEPA filters and activated carbon. Check the CADR rating - higher is better for larger rooms.
Yes, air purifiers work! Use them in bedrooms and main living areas. Keep doors/windows closed and run continuously for best results.
Major sources include vehicle emissions, industrial activities, power plants, construction, burning of crops, and household cooking with biomass fuels.
Air pollution comes from traffic, factories, coal power plants, waste burning, construction dust, and natural sources like wildfires and dust storms.
Urban pollution is mainly from vehicles and industries. In some areas, crop burning, brick kilns, and residential heating contribute significantly.
Winter pollution is often worse due to temperature inversion, heating emissions, and crop burning. Cold air traps pollutants near the ground.
Pollution varies by season. Winter has higher PM levels due to heating and trapped air. Summer sees more ozone formation from heat and sunlight.
In many regions, air quality worsens in winter due to crop burning, increased heating needs, and weather conditions that trap pollutants.
Indoor air can be 2-5 times more polluted than outdoor air. Sources include cooking, cleaning products, and poor ventilation. Use air purifiers and proper ventilation.
Improve indoor air by avoiding smoking indoors, using exhaust fans while cooking, maintaining AC filters, and using air purifiers during high outdoor AQI.
Indoor pollution comes from cooking fumes, incense, cleaning chemicals, and outdoor pollution entering through windows. Keep indoor plants and use HEPA purifiers.
Air pollution during pregnancy can affect fetal development and birth weight. Pregnant women should minimize exposure, especially in the first trimester.
Expectant mothers should stay indoors when AQI is high, use air purifiers at home, and avoid areas with heavy traffic.
Studies link air pollution exposure during pregnancy to preterm birth and low birth weight. Take extra precautions and monitor air quality daily.
Air pollution is a major asthma trigger. Asthmatics should stay indoors when AQI exceeds 100, keep rescue inhalers handy, and use preventive medication as prescribed.
For asthma patients: monitor AQI daily, avoid outdoor activities during high pollution, use air purifiers, and follow your asthma action plan closely.
Pollution can trigger asthma attacks. Track your peak flow, take controller medications regularly, and seek medical attention if symptoms worsen.
Indoor plants can help improve air quality by absorbing CO2 and some pollutants. Snake plants, spider plants, and peace lilies are particularly effective.
While plants do clean air, you'd need many to match an air purifier's effectiveness. They're great additions but shouldn't be your only solution.
Plants like Areca Palm, Money Plant, and Aloe Vera can improve indoor air quality. Place several in each room for best results.

patterns: How does weather affect air quality?
responses: Rain helps wash pollutants from the air. Wind can disperse pollution but also carry it from other areas. Calm, stagnant conditions trap pollution.
Temperature inversions in winter trap pollutants near ground level. Windy conditions help disperse pollution, while rain provides temporary relief.
Weather significantly impacts air quality. Rain and wind improve it, while temperature inversions and calm conditions worsen pollution.
Please use the dashboard to check the current AQI for your location. You can search for your city in the search bar.
You can view real-time AQI data on the dashboard. Just enter your city name or enable location access.
Check the main dashboard for current AQI readings. The map view also shows pollution levels across different areas.
Check the forecast tab on the dashboard for predicted AQI levels for the next few days.
Air quality forecasts are available on the dashboard. They help you plan outdoor activities in advance.
The dashboard provides 3-7 day air quality forecasts based on weather patterns and pollution trends.
Use the search function on the dashboard to check AQI for any city. You can also enable location access for automatic local updates.
Enter your city name in the search bar to get location-specific air quality data and recommendations.
The dashboard supports air quality data for cities worldwide. Just type in the location you want to check.
Our data comes from government monitoring stations and verified air quality networks to ensure accuracy and reliability.
We aggregate data from official environmental monitoring agencies and real-time sensor networks.
Air quality data is sourced from certified monitoring stations and updated regularly to provide accurate, real-time information.

patterns: Alert me when AQI is high
responses: You can set up personalized AQI alerts in the settings menu. Get notifications when air quality reaches your specified threshold.
Enable notifications to receive alerts when AQI levels become unhealthy in your area.
Customize alert settings to get notified about poor air quality, allowing you to take precautions in advance.
Access historical air quality data through the dashboard's history tab. View trends over days, months, or years.
The dashboard archives historical AQI data, allowing you to analyze pollution patterns and seasonal variations.
Historical data helps identify long-term trends. You can view past AQI levels and compare them with current conditions.
Use the comparison feature to view air quality across multiple cities side by side.
The dashboard allows you to compare AQI levels between different locations to help with travel or relocation decisions.
Compare cities to see which areas have better air quality. This feature is useful for planning trips or considering relocations.
